thread.title: Update: Former Cardinals receiver Michael Floyd begins serving his 24-day sentence in Maricopa County Jail

text:
CLOSE Skip in Skip x Embed
x Share
Not everyone is happy that ex-Cardinals WR Michael Floyd, who was waived by the Cardinals three days after an arrest on suspicion of driving under the influence, is a Super Bowl champion. Video: azcentral sports Wochit 
Michael Floyd is a Super Bowl champion. (Photo: Elise Amendola, AP) 
79 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Michael Floyd has begun serving a 24-day sentence in jail, to be followed by more than three months of house arrest, for an extreme DUI, records show.
The former Arizona Cardinals wide receiver pleaded guilty Thursday in a Scottsdale city court. Records show he reported to jail almost immediately after.
Floyd made the plea in exchange for the city prosecutor dropping other charges against him, including failure to obey a police officer and obstructing a public thoroughfare.
Scottsdale City Court Judge Joseph Olcavage gave Floyd a 120-day sentence; the first 24 of those days will be spent in jail.
Floyd will begin 96 days of home detention March 13 and is forbidden from consuming any alcohol. He must also attend alcohol-abuse screening and complete treatment recommended by counselors.
In addition, Floyd must do 30 hours of community restitution and pay a total of $5,115.99 in fees and fines.
Floyd had a blood-alcohol level of 0.217 percent when police stopped him early Dec. 12, according to results from the Scottsdale Police Department crime laboratory. Floyd, 27, was found asleep at the wheel of a 2017 Cadillac Escalade near Goldwater Boulevard and Camelback Road.
Under Arizona law, extreme DUI is defined as a blood-alcohol concentration of 0.15 percent or higher within two hours of driving or being in actual control of a vehicle.
Floyd was claimed by the New England Patriots after the Cardinals waived him in mid-December, three days after his arrest.
He did not play in the Super Bowl, but after the Patriots' win, Floyd posted a defiant tweet that miffed many Arizona sports fans .
"Damn I just realized ppl are really mad that I got a ring," he said. "I thought everyone would be happy for me. Oh well. I'm a champion!!"
Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Celebrities arrested in metro Phoenix   Fullscreen Post to Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 
The Valley has a long history of celebs — from sports figures to rock stars to actors — landing themselves in handcuffs here.  Getty Images Fullscreen Authorities arrested rock star Jim Morrison, singer for the band Doors, in November of 1969 after being disruptive on a flight to Phoenix. Once the plane landed, the FBI took Morrison and a friend into custody, according to ultimateclassicrock.com, which cited the Morrison biography No One Here Gets Out Alive.  Elektra Records Fullscreen Danny Bonaduce: Authorities arrested the Partridge Family actor in 1991 after Phoenix police said he beat a transvestite prostitute.  Getty Images Fullscreen Police arrested the Motley Crue drummer Tommy Lee, along with bandmate Nikki Sixx, in December of 1997 after authorities said they knocked over a security guard at a concert at then-named America West Arena. Lee encouraged fans to come on stage after the concert and when the security guard tried to hold back the fans, Lee and Sixx tried to subdue him, according to the Associated Press.  MCSO Fullscreen Police arrested the Motley Crue bassist Nikki Sixx, along with bandmate Tommy Lee, in December of 1997 after authorities said they knocked over a security guard at a concert at then-named America West Arena. Lee encouraged fans to come on stage after the concert and when the security guard tried to hold back the fans, Lee and Sixx tried to subdue him, according to the Associated Press.  MCSO Fullscreen Former Arizona Cardinals running back Mario Bates was arrested in Scottsdale in March of 2000 after police said he slapped his girlfriend in the face. He later pleaded guilty and was given two years of probation and a $364 fine. Bates also played for the New Orleans Saints and the Detroit Lions.  The Republic Fullscreen Former Pittsburgh Steelers offensive tackle Marvel Smith was accused of marijuana possession after Tempe police were called to his hotel about the smell in 2002. The charges were later dropped.  USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Phoenix police arrested Grammy winner Glen Campbell on suspicion of drunk driving and aggravated assault on Nov. 24, 2003. Police said he struck another vehicle, fled the scene and kicked a police officer who questioned him. He later served 10 days in Tent City and even performed for inmates.  The Republic Fullscreen Police arrested former Baltimore Ravens linebacker Terrell Suggs on suspicion of assault after a fight in a Phoenix parking lot in 2003. He was later acquitted by a jury. Suggs ran into law enforcement again in March of 2016 on charges of failing to stop and notify the owner of a collision and for driving while his driver`s license was suspended after he crashed into a curb with his BMW.  USA Today Sports Fullscreen Police arrested the retired Arizona Cardinals football player Michael Pittman in June of 2003 in Phoenix after police said he drove his Hummer into his wife’s Mercedes. His wife’s vehicle was carrying his 2-year-old child and a babysitter. Pittman later pleaded guilty to felony endangerment.  USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Police arrested fitness guru Richard Simmons after he slapped a Mesa MMA fighter who was teasing him while at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport on March 25, 2004. The case was later dismissed.  Associated Press Fullscreen Former MLB slugger Albert Belle was arrested in May of 2006 after police said he stalked and threatened his ex-girlfriend in Scottsdale. Initial stalking allegations arose in February of 2006 when his ex claimed Belle had tapped a tracking device to her vehicle. Maricopa County Superior Court ordered Belle to leave his ex-girlfriend alone, but Belle ignored these demands.  MCSO Fullscreen Scottsdale police arrested boxer Mike Tyson on suspicion of driving under the influence in December of 2006 after he was seen wiping a white powder off the vehicle’s dashboard when police approached him, according to officials. Tyson told police he had been using cocaine that day and was an addict. He was also cited on suspicion of felony criminal damage in 2004 after he was accused of damaging a car outside of a club, but the complaint was later dropped.  MCSO Fullscreen Former Seattle Seahawks player Jerramy Stevens was arrested in Scottsdale on suspicion of driving under the influence and possession of marijuana in 2007. He previously faced drunken driving charges in Seattle in 2003 and was accused of breaking a man’s jaw with a baseball bat in 1998.  Scottsdale Police Department Fullscreen US Airways CEO Doug Parker was arrested Jan. 31, 2007, in Scottsdale on suspicion of driving under the influence after he was pulled over for driving 20 miles over the speed limit. Tests show Parker had a blood alcohol level of 0.096, according to officials. He was sentenced to serve one day in jail and fined.  Associated Press Fullscreen New York rapper DMX was arrested in Phoenix in July of 2008 on suspicion of using another identity while at Metrocenter mall. The rapper, whose real name is Earl Simmons, was also arrested a few months prior at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport on outstanding warrants for failing to appear in court.  MCSO Fullscreen NBA star Charles Barkley was arrested on suspicion of misdemeanor DUI and being impaired to the slightest degree in December 2008. He told police he was on his way to receive oral sex from the woman with him in the vehicle when he rolled through a stop sign in Scottsdale, according to police records.  Gilbert Police Department Fullscreen In February of 2009, former Phoenix Suns player Jason Richardson was arrested on suspicion of endangerment, reckless driving, failure to use a child seat and excessive speed after Scottsdale police said he drove at 90 mph in a 35 mph zone with his 3-year-old son unrestrained in the vehicle. Richardson was also cited in December of 2008 on suspicion of driving under the influence in Mesa, Ariz.  Tom Tingle/The Republic Fullscreen The then-Detroit Tigers catcher Gerald Laird and his brother and uncle were arrested after a brawl at a Phoenix bar in December of 2009. Laird was arrested on suspicion of misdemeanor assault.  USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen New York Yankees player Brandon Laird and brother of Gerald Laird, was arrested during a brawl at a Phoenix bar in December of 2009. He was arrested on suspicion of misdemeanor disorderly conduct.  USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Former NHL player Nikolai Khabibulin, who spend part of his career as a goalie for the Arizona Coyotes, was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence and speeding in February 2010 in Paradise Valley. Khabibulin was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $1,507.  Scottsdale Police Department Fullscreen Oakland Athletics center fielder Covelli Loyce "Coco" Crisp was arrested on suspicion of driving while impaired in Scottsdale while his team was in Arizona for spring training in March of 2011. Crisp was cited for driving while impaired, having a BAC of 0.08 percent or more, driving with an expired California registration, failure to drive in a single lane and no proof of current insurance, police said.  Associated Press Fullscreen Actor Kiowa Gordon, who played Embry Call in the Twilight movie series, was arrested in August of 2011 by Tempe police after failing to appear in Mesa and Scottsdale courts for previous arrests. In January of 2010, Gordon was arrested on charges of being a minor in possession of alcohol and for possession of marijuana during a traffic citation.  MCSO Fullscreen 'Lean on Me' actor Jermaine Hopkins was arrested in December of 2011 after authorities said he bought 200 pounds of marijuana from an undercover officer in Phoenix, according to the Associated Press. Hopkins served 30 days in jail after pleading guilty to marijuana possession for sale. Hopkins also served three years on probation.  MCSO Fullscreen Australian golfer and Scottsdale resident Matthew Giles was arrested on suspicion of drunken driving after he crashed into a Gilbert home in April 2012.  USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Former baseball announcer Mark Grace had two DUI arrests in a 15 month period. Police say Grace was driving without an interlock device in violation of his probation. After the second, which occurred in August 2012, he was jailed for four months.  Scottsdale Police Department Fullscreen Former Phoenix Suns forward Richard Dumas was arrested on suspicion of eight counts of organized retail theft in Litchfield Park in September and October of 2012. In late 2014, a judge dismissed seven counts of shoplifting charges, but Dumas later plead guilty to two counts of theft in December.  The Republic Fullscreen The 'Dazed and Confused' actor Jason London was arrested on suspicion of assault and disorderly conduct after an altercation at a Scottsdale bar in January of 2013. A heavily intoxicated London allegedly sneezed in the face of another man, and when the man asked London to apologize, London struck the man in the face, according to police records.  Stephen Lovekin/Getty Images Fullscreen Former Suns player Michael Beasley was arrested on suspicion of drug possession after Scottsdale police contacted him for an alleged traffic violation and smelled marijuana coming from his car in August of 2013. An undisclosed amount of narcotics were also seized from the vehicle.  The Republic Fullscreen Suns broadcaster Tom Chambers was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence to the slightest degree in December 2013. He told Scottsdale police he had drank a few beers at the ASU PAC-12 championship game that night, according to police records.  The Republic Fullscreen Tempe police said 41-year-old actor Colin Egglesfield, known for his roles on "The Client List" and "All My Children", was arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and criminal damage in April of 2014. Authorities said Egglesfield was arrested on allegations that he damaged property at the Tempe Festival of the Arts.  Tempe Police Department/AP Photo Fullscreen Phoenix Suns player was arrested on suspicion of “super extreme DUI” in May of 2014 by Scottsdale police. Tucker plead guilty to the super extreme DUI charge, and served three days in jail and 11 days of home detention. Tucker also installed an interlock ignition device on his car for 18 months, paid a fine and submitted to substance abuse screenings.  USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Arizona Cardinals running back Jonathan Dwyer was arrested at the team’s Tempe training facility on suspicion of aggravated assault. Police said Dwyer head-butted his wife and broke her nose during a dispute in July of 2014. Dwyer plead guilty to one count of disorderly conduct and served 18 months of probation and community service.  David KadlubowskI/The Republic Fullscreen Police said the former Arizona Cardinals quarterback Max Hall was allegedly in possession of stolen items and cocaine in a Gilbert Best Buy in September of 2014, according to police. Police were called to the store after an employee reportedly saw Hall taking merchandise out of boxes and stuffing them in his backpack.  Gilbert Police Department Fullscreen In September of 2014, former Suns guard Rex Chapman was arrested on suspicion of stealing more than $14,000 in merchandise from the Scottsdale Quarter Apple store on separate occasions over the course of several weeks. Chapman plead guilty to four felony theft charges and was sentenced to 18 months of supervised probation.  Gilbert Police Department Fullscreen NFL Hall of Famer Warren Sapp was arrested in February of 2015 in Phoenix on suspicion of assault and soliciting a prostitute after an incident at a downtown Phoenix hotel. Sapp was in town with the NFL Network for Super Bowl XLIX and was fired from his network analyst job shortly after his arrest. A Phoenix city judge dismissed the solicitation charge after his successful completion of a diversion program,  Maricopa County Sheriff's Office Fullscreen Former Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Donovan McNabb was arrested in late June 2015 on suspicion of drunk driving after police say he rear-ended another vehicle in Gilbert. In December of 2014, McNabb served one day in jail for speeding along Loop 101, and was also cited for DUI.  Gilbert Police Department Fullscreen Former Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Donovan McNabb was arrested in late June 2015 on suspicion of drunk driving after police say he rear-ended another vehicle in Gilbert. In December of 2014, McNabb served one day in jail for speeding along Loop 101, and was also cited for DUI.  Gilbert Police Department Fullscreen Scottsdale police arrested 'Days of Our Lives' actor Casey Moss on Oct. 26, 2015 after he attempted to punch a bartender at a posh hotel bar in Scottsdale. Moss was expected to face charges of assault, disorderly conduct and resisting arrest.  Scottsdale Police Department Fullscreen Houston Texans wide receiver and former Arizona State football player Jaelen Strong was arrested in Scottsdale in February of 2016 on suspicion of marijuana possession.  Scottsddale Police Department Fullscreen Former Arizona Cardinals wide receiver Michael Floyd was arrested in December of 2016 after being found asleep at the wheel in the middle of a Scottsdale intersection. Floyd, who later proved to have been driving with a blood-alcohol level of 0.217 percent, faced charges of driving under the influence and failure to obey a police officer.  Scottsdale Police Department Fullscreen Australian pro golfer Steven David Bowditch was arrested on suspicion of extreme DUI in Scottsdale around 1:00 a.m. on Feb. 3, 2017. The golfer, who was competing in the Waste Management Phoenix Open, had a blood-alcohol content exceeding 0.20 percent and was seen swerving on the road. Bowditch released an apology shortly after his arrest.  Tom Pennington, Getty Images Fullscreen Like this topic?
